titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. VI. Tuesday— Finished the Draft of Instructions to H. Middleton upon the North-west Coast question— My time is swallowed up in the examination of Cook’s third Voyage, Coxe’s Russian discoveries, Humboldt, Mackenzie, Lewis and Clarke, and the annual register for 1790. for research into this question— I find proof enough to put down the Russian argument; but how shall we answer the Russian Cannon? Mr Joseph Nancrede came to request my aid to his solicitation for the restoration of his Son as a Cadet at West-Point— He has been dismissed for neglect of mathematical studies— But he has a taste for Poetry. If he cannot be entirely restored Mr Nancrede wishes that he may be put back one year— I promised to speak to the Secretary of War in his behalf. Mr Peter Hagner called— Anxious for Captain Randall on his Mission to the Havanna, for fear of the yellow fever— I told him Captain Randall’s Instructions authorized him to resort to healthy places during the sickly Season—though I was not without concern for him myself— At the Office. Mr Preble came to enquire, if vouchers had been applied for to the Spanish Government in the case of the Eliza, a vessel in which he had an interest. They had. Coll. Freeman came to ask a copy of the fac-simile engraving of the Declaration of Independence, which I have had made— I told him that I thought it was public property the distribution of which I should refer to a Resolution of Congress— I called at the
President’s with several Letters, and mentioned to him the substance of my conversations yesterday with Baron Tuyll and Count de Menou— Evening with George at the Play Isabella, and the Irishman in London.

2. VI.W. F. Bourne a son of the former Consul at Amsterdam, came this morning with an application for a Commission in the Marine Corps— He brought me a Letter from his brother— I enquired if he had not been in South America. He said he had, but did not seem willing to say more on that subject— I told him his application must be to the Secretary of the Navy— Mr Rice came to make some enquiries concerning the Columbian College Stock— Lieutenant Kirby called, with a request from General Brown, for a loan of the Senate Journals— At the Office there came a Mr Miller, from Virginia, applying for employment, with a recommendation from the President, and one from Mr Wirt— Dr Sewall from a Committee of persons who propose to keep the celebration of the Independence day at Mount-Vernon— I declined on account of an engagement to accompany the President to the celebration at the Capitol— But Dr Sewall came again to ask my attendance at the dinner at Alexandria, which the Mount-Vernon party intend— I promised an answer to-morrow— In the Evening I returned the visit of Messrs.Sullivan and Pearce, but they were at the President’s— Johnson Hellen unwell— And Mrs Adams.

3. V: I began a Letter of Instruction to R. Rush upon the North-west Coast question— This subject still absorbs my time so that I cannot pay due attention to many others— I received a Summons about one O’Clock to attend at the President’s immediately. I found all the members of the Administration there— And also Mr Peter Hagner the third Auditor— The business on which the Meeting had been assembled was already done. It was that the President should approve a partial adjustment of the Vice-Presidents accounts, making him as I understood a new allowance of about 46000 dollars— At the Office Mr John Connell came; recently returned from France. He had a long conversation with me, about claims of our Merchants upon France, and also upon Denmark, which they wish now to revive. Connell afterwards dined with us, and passed the Evening here till ten— Among other things he intimated to me that G. W. Erving was writing against me in the newspapers at New-York. Erving has taken a passion to be Minister in France, in place of Mr Gallatin, and very erroneously ascribes to me the President’s indisposition to appoint him— Johnson Hellen was confined to his bed.

4. V:30. Independence day— At half past 11. I went to the President’s and found there, Mr Crawford, Mr Thompson and Mr Wirt; also the Vice-President, Mr G. Hay, and Mr Sullivan, who went with the President to the Capitol— We all followed, except Mr Wirt— Mr Calhoun joined the company at the Capitol— The House was not full. There was a short prayer by Mr Hawley, the Declaration of Independence was read by Mr Richard Bland Lee accompanied with some remarks, and an Oration was delivered by Coll. Henry Ashton. We then all returned home. After dinner I took a ride with Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen. Mr Addington spent the Evening with us; which was cool and pleasant. I found that none of the other members of the Administration joined the Mount Vernon party at Alexandria; and therefore felt myself released from the obligation of attending it myself— The day was given almost entirely to leisure—though I wrote about a page of the Instructions to R. Rush about the North-west Coast— At dinner we remembered John, who is this day twenty.

5. VI.Mr. W. F. Bourne, son of the late Sylvanus Bourne, Consul of the United States at Amsterdam came to the Office, and said he had called upon the Secretary of the Navy, and solicited the appointment of Captain in the Marine Corps. The Secretary had told him the appointment would be decided upon by the President, and would be made this day— I called at the President’s, and recommended Bourne to him. He said he would consider of it. I left with the President the papers received from T. Randall at St. John’s Porto-Rico; and suggested the necessity of some further measures for the protection of our Commerce— The President directed a Cabinet Meeting on Monday at one O’Clock, and said he intended to go to Loudoun on Tuesday— There was a thunder shower this Evening.

6. V:30.Mr George Hay was this morning at my house, with some queries, which he said had been put to him, and which he wished to answer. They related to his Agency, before the Commission, not yet in Session, under the Slave-indemnity Convention— Whether he would be authorised to act in behalf of individual claimants; whether they would be allowed to employ other agents or Council; and whether he might accept any compensation from individuals— I said I presumed he might appear for each and every Claimant. That each claimant would also have the power to appear before the Commissioners in person or by any agent whom he might appoint. But the Commissioners themselves I supposed would determine, whom and in what manner they would hear the claims— As to the question whether Mr Hay could with propriety receive compensation from individual claimants I did not feel myself competent to give an opinion. Mr Hay spoke in terms of great severity of Ritchie, the Editor of the Richmond Enquirer; and said he was the most unprincipled fellow upon Earth, whose whole Efforts would be to work himself into the side of the majority. He was now endeavouring to buy up the Newspaper lately established in Richmond against him, the Virginia Times— The Richmond Enquirer has been for several years the political barometer of the State of Virginia— I attended Church with Mrs Adams, morning and afternoon at Mr Baker’s Morning Sermon from Acts 17.11. [“]These were more noble than those of Thessalonica, in that they received the word with all readiness of mind, and searched the Scriptures daily whether these things were so.” Very urgent exhortations to search the Scriptures— Admonition, rebuke, and toleration. afternoon text from Psalm 99.1. “The Lord reigneth; let the people tremble”—a commination. I finished the draft of Instructions to R. Rush, on the North-west Coast question— We dined late. In the evening I heard Mr Little; from Revelations 6.12.13.14. [“]And I beheld, when he had opened the sixth seal; and lo, there was a great earthquake; and the sun became black as sackcloth of hair, and the moon became as blood;—and the stars of heaven fell unto the earth even as a fig tree casteth her untimely figs, when she is shaken of a mighty wind—and the Heaven departed as a scrowl when it is rolled together; and every mountain and island were moved out of their places.”— It was a sort of Independence day Oration— But Dr Thornton was not pleased with it. He said the idea of the stars of Heaven falling to the Earth was very unphilosophical.

7. VI. Swam this Morning with Antoine in the Potowmack. Went for the first time to the Bridge, and returned with some difficulty against the tide which was going out— About one hour in the Water— B. O. Tyler came with more books for sale— He told me that Mr Crawford was now the owner of the Washington Gazette, in the name of General Van Ness, to whom the whole establishment has been transferred. At the Office. Mr Christopher Hughes junr. Charge d’Affaires at
Stockholm, but visiting this Country on a leave of absence, came and passed an hour with me; reviewing all his adventures, since we were together at Ghent— Cabinet Meeting at the President’s— All there— The subject for Consideration was whether new and enlarged instructions should be given to our naval Officers in the West-Indies to protect our merchant vessels, and recapture them if they should be taken— The despatch from T. Randall was read— It was finally concluded to do nothing at present— Mr Crawford said if any measure was to be taken, it would be better against Spain relapsed, than against Spain regenerated. Mr Wirt thought that since our last treaty with Spain, our vessels could not cover French property from Spanish capture, even if France acknowledged the principle that free ships make free goods; because she is not bound to acknowledge it by Treaty— In the Evening I rode out with Mrs Adams, Mary and Johnson Hellen and George, to the place which was the late Mr Orr’s— It is now uninhabited, and Mrs Adams had thoughts of taking it for about six weeks; but I could not go there. The house was locked up— Antoine and his wife have given notice of their intention to leave us, about the end of next Month— The Coachman and house-maid are also going away.

8. VI. Swam with Antoine in the Potowmack—to the Bridge— One hour in the water. While we were swimming there sprung up a fresh breeze, which made a surf and much increased the difficulty of swimming—especially against it and the current— This is one of the varieties of instruction for the school. It some times occurs to me that this exercise and amusement as I am now indulging myself in it is with the constant risk of life. Perhaps that is the reason, why so few persons ever learn to swim— And perhaps it should now teach me discretion— Mr Rice called at my house and will call again upon the Columbian College pecuniary concerns— At the Office, a Mr Boardman, an Alabama printer of U.S. Laws, with an account to be paid— Mr Parish, to say that Mr Canning would remain yet about a week at New-York, before he will embark, and to enquire if I should reply to two Notes received from him there— Complaints against H. Strong our Consul at Glasgow— I told Mr Parish that there were certain examinations which I must make before answering in this case, which would take so much time that I should probably not be able to answer before Mr Canning’s departure— The Count de Menou, came to enquire where were the Quirpon Islands: I shewed him upon Mitchell’s map— We had much conversation upon the subject of the french claim to exclusive fishery from them to Cape Ray— He said he had received further Instructions from the Viscount de Chateaubriand, on this affair; but there were still two previous instructions which he had not received. He saw it was an affair of great delicacy; and he did not see how they and we could enjoy a concurrent right of fishery on the same coast— I told him, the whole affair was a question between France and Great-Britain, with which we had but a secondary concern— Great Britain was bound to maintain her own jurisdiction. And if she had conceded to us a right which she had already granted as an exclusive possession to France, she must indemnify us for it. The Count spoke also upon the subject of the maritime questions arisen from the War between France and Spain; upon which he said he should write to me— We examined the State-papers, and found Mr Jefferson’s answer to Genet of 24. July 1793. and the reference to it in Mr Pickering’s Instructions to Messrs. Marshall, Pinkney and Gerry. It was as I had stated yesterday to Mr Wirt— Mr Jefferson’s assertion of the principle that enemy’s property is liable to capture and condemnation in the vessel of a friend is not absolute— His words are, I believe it cannot be doubted— C. Hughes came and left with me several papers relating to our affairs with Sweden. Edelhierta—discriminating duties— Consul at St. Bartholomews— I called at the President’s. He has postponed his departure for Loudoun till to-morrow. He intends to come here again to
meet Mr Gallatin, about eight or ten days hence, and he has requested Mr Hughes to come here again, about the same time. He approved without alteration the Draft of Instructions to Rush on the Northwest Coast question, and the Observations on the Russian Claims. I dined at Mr Calhoun’s with a party of eleven. No Lady— Just before dinner, Mr M’Lean, the new Postmaster General was called out, by an express from Baltimore with news that the Mail had been robbed last Night about 16 miles from that place, coming from Philadelphia. As we were about rising from table Mr M’Lean returned; having by a second express been informed that three of the Robbers were taken—two of them wounded by the Guard— Mr Hughes walked home, and sat with me talking till eleven— Mrs Adams and George were at the Theatre.

9. VI: Swam in the Potowmack one hour with Antoine. The President went to Loudoun. Mr Thomas Law came to my house, and told me he was about to publish in the Newspapers a series of Essays under the signature of Senex, to which he requested my particular attention. They would settle entirely the currency question, by proving the utter impossibility of a circulating medium in gold— They would also prove the absolute necessity of issues of Bank paper. But he was afraid he should displease Mr Crawford, as he should be obliged to point out errors in his report. At the Office. W. F. Bourne came to enquire if he had obtained the appointment which he had solicited in the Marine Corps— I told him I had recommended him to the President, but referred him to the Secretary of the Navy for a definitive answer. I wrote to Jacob and H. Schieffelin. Dr Thornton came and spent an hour with me this Evening. Exceedingly anxious that an Agent should be sent to the Greeks— The summer heat how raging in all its fierceness almost disqualifies me for writing.

10. V:30. Swam with Antoine to and from the Bridge—but as the tide was strongly rising we were full three quarters of an hour in going to it, and not more than twenty minutes in returning. This was one of my swimming lessons, and a serious admonition to caution. I had no visitors this day; but yesterday General Van Ness, brought me a Letter from Mr H. Allen the Minister newly appointed to Chile, saying he should be very glad to have Mr B. T. Watts to go with him as Secretary of Legation; and Genl. Van Ness was solicitous to know, what would be his prospects of obtaining the appointment— I did not know, and said that possibly Mr Allen might not go to Chile at-all—as his Mission might perhaps be transferred to Mexico— At the Office. I wasted the time this day— Fahrenheit at 92. Evening at the Play— Venice preserved and No Song no Supper— The Secretary of the Navy and Mrs and Miss Thompson were there.

11. VI— And I commence upon my 57th. year. Swam with Antoine an hour in the Potowmack— We started for the Bridge; but after swimming about half an hour, I perceived by reference to a house upon the shore, beyond which we were to pass, that we had ascended very little above where we had left our clothes, and that the current of the tide was insensibly carrying us into the middle of the river— We continued struggling against the tide about twenty minutes longer, without apparently gaining a foot upon the tide— I then turned back and in fifteen minutes landed at the rock where I had left my Clothes, upon which in the interval the tide had so much encroached, that it began
to wet them and in another half hour would have soaked them through, or floated them away. We had been an hour and five minutes in the water, without touching ground, and before turning back, I began to find myself weary— At my house B. O. Tyler came about the books he had for sale, and an engraved portrait of my father— George Johnson a cousin of Mrs. Adams’s came to request me to purchase Mills in this neighbourhood which have belonged to him, and upon which he says he has spent near sixty thousand dollars; but which he has conveyed in trust, for a debt to the Bank of Columbia— The debt is 20000 dollars; and they are willing to receive payment of it by yearly instalments in five years— But to set the Mills at Work, from ten to twelve thousand dollars more are necessary as capital, to purchase wheat, and pay the charges of the establishment— G. Johnson can raise no part of this money, and unless he can make some other arrangement with the Bank before next Thursday, they will rent out the Mills as their property and turn him adrift upon the world— He urged me to buy the Mills for 20000 dollars—to furnish from 10 to 12000 dollars to set and keep them constantly at work— To put them under his management for such portion of the profits as I shall think proper; and reserve to him the right of repurchasing half the Estate on his paying ten thousand dollars— I have taken time for consideration of this proposal, to the acceptance of which many motives, all just and virtuous urge me; but which I cannot accept but at great hazard, and with deep stakes to myself and my family— I promised to answer definitively before next Thursday— At the Office, I met C. Hughes, who goes to-morrow for Baltimore— He claims a second Outfit as Charge d’Affaires; and wished to have a demand made, for the admission duty free of his wines &c— I told him if there must be correspondence about it he must make the claim in writing which he declined— The Baron de Tuyll, called about some despatches that he is sending to Count Lieven, and the Count de Menou, left a note written by Instructions from the Viscount de Chateaubriand: expressing regret at the departure of Mr Gallatin, and professing a readiness to negotiate, concerning the claims of our Citizens, and concerning that of France under the Louisiana Treaty— I told Menou, that we should not connect them together. That the subject of the Louisiana Treaty claim had been exhausted— The views of the American Government concerning it had been fully set forth, and were not changed— If France had anything further to say upon it, we should always be ready to give it due consideration; but could not connect it with our claims in Negotiation— I said this the more freely, because I knew that Mr Gallatin had very explicitly said as much to the Viscount de Chateaubriand— After dinner I rode out with Mrs. Adams, Johnson Hellen and George, to the Columbian Mills, on Rock Creek. They are in rather a neglected condition, but appear to be a valuable property— The heat of the weather continues unabated.

12. VI. Swam an hour with Antoine in the Potowmack. We approached nearer to the Bridge than yesterday, but still without reaching it— I was without interruption at the Office; and wrote a Letter to General Dearborn, Minister at Lisbon— Mrs Adams and George went to the Play; but I was deterred from going, by the excessive heat of the weather— It has been this week unremitting. Mr Nancrede called upon me after dinner, to renew the request that I would speak to Mr Calhoun, in favour of his Son, for restoration to West Point— He says Mr Calhoun told him, he should wait to make his decision till the return of General Macomb, who made the
examination at the Academy— George Johnson was here about the sale of the Mills, and gave me further information concerning them— This affair involves the comfort of my future life, and that of all my family— My personal independence, and a system of projected occupation for the remnant of my life, after my retirement from the public Service. That event is approaching, and now so near at hand, that it is time seriously to provide for it— Less than two years will terminate my political career, and leave me to the support of my private resources— Is not this a gracious offer by Providence of the means of devoting the time which may yet be allotted upon Earth, to useful and respectable purposes? Such is the hope I have conceive— But it is yet beclouded with doubts, and beset with perils— It must be at-all Events, in a great degree a leap in the dark— But man must trust— Of my motives I am sure— G. Johnson is to bring me further papers on Monday.

13. V:30.Mrs Adams was again quite ill in the Night, and all this day— Weather cooler. Suspended my visits to the Potowmack— Heard Mr Little, A.M. from Galatians 1.23.24. [“]But they had heard only, that he which persecuted us in times past now preacheth the faith which once he destroyed— And they glorified God in me”— A sort of Dissertation upon the Conversion of St. Paul— It also testified with much satisfaction to the increasing numbers of Christians with liberal opinions— In the afternoon I heard Mr Baker from Lament: 3.39.40. “Wherefore doth a living man complain, a man for the punishment of his sins? Let us search and try our ways, and turn again to the Lord.” A funeral Sermon; upon occasion of the Death of Mr Bromley, one of the Elders of the Church— In the Evening I heard again Mr Little, from the 23d. Psalm— Also a funeral discourse, on the decease in England, of the Mother of one of the members of the Church— There were two visitors left Cards while I was out this day. A Mr Johnston, and Mr R. I. Linzee from Boston. It appears that Spain has proved as Craven to her Revolution as Naples— Johnson Hellen and George went this day to Rockville.

14. VI.George Johnson came and brought an original deed of the land which I have agreed to purchase on the terms proposed by him, to which I suggested some slight modifications— He left with me a paper containing his proposals— But I found he was not entirely sure that the Bank of Columbia, which has now the title, will make the conveyance— I desired him therefore to see General Mason, the President of that Bank, and ascertain the fact— After dinner I went out with George to the place, and took a partial view of its location. Mr Johnson gave me also three plots with a description of the boundaries; but General Mason had not been altogether explicit with him as to the conveyance— But the Estate really belonged to Roger Johnson, George’s Father, the conveyances have been made by him and to him is reserved the right to redeem the Estate. George goes therefore to-morrow to Frederick to see his father, and is to return, and see me again on Wednesday Evening— His wife and three small children were at the house. On further reflection upon my purposed course in this affair, it appears to me, that if it should prosper my plan must be to enable him to reacquire the whole Estate. He asks only the reserved right of redeeming half of it, at the price which I am now to pay. To this I immediately agreed; but as a tenancy in Common would be inconvenient both to
him and me, I wish to provide on fair terms for the whole property’s becoming ultimately his or mine— Mr D. De Ferrest, heretofore titular Consul from Buenos-Ayres, but whose Commission has been recently revoked called at my house— He is here upon a claim under the Florida Treaty— Dr Staughton the President of the Columbian College and Mr Ira Chase one of the Professors called to ask a Letter of Introduction for Mr Chase to Mr Rush; and a Passport— Both of which I promised— At the Office came Mr Johnston of Baltimore who was here last winter, and who has since been at an Indian factory near Nachitoches— Mr Thompson the Secretary of the Navy, came to say that he had no vessel now to dispose of by which he could send Manuel Pereira, sentenced at Charleston, S.C. as a Pirate, to the Havanna— He left the papers with me— I spoke to him in favour of J. Amory’sson for a midshipman’s warrant, and of W. F. Bourne for a Commission in the Marine Corps; I fear without effect— I wrote to President Kirkland, and to Mr Lloyd, and Mr Gallatin.

15. VI.General Joseph G. Swift Surveyor of the Customs at the Port of New-York, came and had two hours of Conversation with me, upon Weights and Measures, the length of the Pendulum; Captain Kater and Captain Sabine; and upon political affairs, in which he takes a very warm interest— Mr Bailey came and introduced a young man named Brown, of Providence, anxious to obtain an appointment as a Secretary of Legation abroad— A Youth by the name of M’Lean came with a Letter of recommendation from Mr Anderson, the Comptroller. He is going to Cambridge, to enter there as a Sophomore, after the next Commencement— I wrote Letters for him to President Kirkland, and to my Son Charles. Mr Anderson himself came to my Office, with papers relating to the Settlement of the late Josiah Meigs’s accounts— There are two charges amounting to 550 dollars, for which there are the strongest presumptions that he ought to be credited, but which not being regularly vouched cannot be admitted at the Treasury. There was among the papers a Report from the Auditor Harrison, unfavourable to one of the claims, but not exact— By persuasion and reasoning I prevailed upon him to promise that he would write to the two persons who have acknowledged receiving the money, to obtain more decisive evidence of the facts. I wrote a short despatch to Mr Middleton— Swift told me that Gallatin since his return has been very busy with Politics, and very transparent in his conversations— Evening at the Theatre— Saw the Spy, a domestic Tragedy, taken from Cooper’s Novel, and written as Burke told me, by Mr Lynch of New-York— The farce was the Rendez-vous— Mrs Adams is better.

16. V:45.Mr Brown was again at my house this morning, exceedingly anxious to obtain an appointment as Secretary of Legation, for which I could give him no encouragement. He pressed with great earnestness the claimsbro of the State of Rhode-Island— A person by the name of Young brought a recommendation with several signatures for an appointment as a Messenger or Watchman in any of the Departments. No vacancy. At the Office came Mr Myer, a lawyer of Baltimore; to enquire concerning a claim of a Mr Karthaus, now before the Florida Treaty Commissioners— I had a Correspondence concerning it, while I was in England. Mr Myers wants some papers which were sent to me then— Mr Chase the professor came and I delivered him Letters of Introduction to R. Rush and A. H. Everett. Johnson Hellen left us and returned to Rockville— Walking with George after dinner, we met Mr Webster who came home and sat an hour with us. Mrs Thornton was here.
I received a Note from George Johnson. His father has returned with him from Frederick.

17. V:30.George Johnson came this Morning and requested me to make in writing a proposition to the President and Directors of the Bank of Columbia, for the payment of his debt and the purchase by me of the Mills. I went to the Branch Bank and made my proposal to the Cashier R. Smith. He said he would write immediately to the Bank at Philadelphia and had no doubt my offers would be accepted, as they were preferable to any others proposed by the Bank of Columbia— I gave my written proposal to G. Johnson to take with him to the Bank of Columbia— Mr Brent called about the Correspondence of the old Congress about to be published. At the Office Baron Tuyll came, and enquired if he might inform his Government that Instructions would be forwarded by Mr Hughes to Mr Middleton, for negotiating on the North-west Coast question. I said he might. He then manifested a desire to know, as much as I was disposed to tell him, as to the purport of those Instructions— I told him as much as I thought prudent, as he observed that it was personally somewhat important to him to be so far confided in here, as to know the general purport of what we intended to propose— I told him specially that we should contest the right of Russia, to any territorial Establishment on this Continent; and that we should assume distinctly the principle that the American Continents are no longer subjects for any new European Colonial Establishments— We had a conversation of an hour or more, at the close of which he said that although there would be difficulties in the Negotiation, he did not foresee that they would be insurmountable— Mr F. C. Gray called—he is here to attend at the meeting of the Florida Commissioners, but will remain here only a day or two longer— I spoke to him of my correspondence with President Kirkland about the late disorders at Harvard University— Mr M’Lean the Postmaster General, came and consulted me respecting the appointment of Postmasters at Exeter New-Hampshire, and at Portland in Maine— There were several candidates at Exeter, all well recommended, but none of whom I personally knew— At Portland a factious intrigue against the Postmaster Ilsley has been got up, and the former Postmaster General actually removed him— He appointed Mark Harris the late Member of Congress, and directed him to send his bond here, which he has done, and taken the Oath of Office—but his Commission has not issued— Ilsley is now here, and M’Lean who has examined the charges against him, and his defence is entirely satisfied of his innocence— I gave him very explicitly to understand that I thought he ought under those circumstances to restore Ilsley. I said I had received urgent Letters in behalf of Ilsley, but considering his case to depend altogether on the question of fact as to the charges against him, I had declined interfering unless at the request of the Postmaster General himself, and Mr Meigs never having spoken to me concerning it, I had not spoken to him— If Mr Ilsley was innocent I thought his restoration was due to his character as much as to the Office.
After dinner I went out with Mrs Adams, Mary Hellen and George to Mr. George Johnson’s, where I found his father Mr Roger Johnson, and Mr James Dunlop. George Johnson gave me General Mason’s answer to my proposals of this Morning. The President and Directors of the Bank of Columbia have accepted them— Dunlop gave me the title deeds to examine— Walked mostly home with George— Thunder-shower which roused me in the night.

18. V:30. Heavy Showers of Rain the whole day— This Affair of the Mills now absorbs too much of my time— I have been preparing a draft of Articles of Agreement with George Johnson to be executed after the purchase shall be completed— This morning I examined all the Deeds received yesterday, and find some links in the chain of evidence wanting— William Mulky came to explain to me a system of orthoèpy for the English language, of which he is the inventor. He proposes to open a school for it here, and wants the patronage of persons connected, with the Government— His own orthoèpy was doubtful, and his Grammar imperfect. I asked him where he had been educated. In Georgia, of which State he was a native; but he said he was not a Greek and Latin Scholar— I told him I thought orthoèpy was fashion, fluctuating in its nature and not susceptible of being fixed— If he should open a School here, I would willingly attend to witness his mode of Instruction—but that I never gave Certificates recommendatory. At the Office, I examined some of the Correspondence of the old Congress which has been ordered to be published— Mr Pomeroy called on me after dinner with Mr Bulfinch—going to Ohio, where he has Coal beds— Solitary walk. Edward Ingersoll of Philadelphia spent the Evening here— To return to-morrow.

19. V— Swam in the Potowmack with Antoine. About three quarters of an hour: we went with great ease to the Bridge; but the tide was going out, and ran so rapidly there that I found great difficulty in stemming it, and came into shallow water as soon as possible— The struggle against the tide was so fatiguing that I soon gave it up, and touched the ground— I have now the lesson both ways, and know experimentally the danger of attempting to swim against a current— At my house, B. O. Tyler came and I agreed to take his Books. George Johnson, with whom I consulted further about the Mills— He said his father thought he should join in the conveyance. I thought so too; but he has gone this day to Frederick. I gave George Johnson, a copy of the drafted Articles between him and me— He now objected to one of them, and wished it altered— I called at the Treasurer’s and transferred U.S. six per Cent Stocks, and sent them to Hale and Davidson at Philadelphia, under cover to N. Biddle, President of the U.S. Bank— At the Office Mr Ilsley the Portland Postmaster came, and asked me for my friendly influence with the President upon his case— Dr Watkins came for funds to pay the contingent expenses of the Florida-Claims Commissioners, for which he must now apply at the Treasury Department— Went this Evening with George to the Theatre. Saw Othello, by Booth, very indifferent; and Lover’s Quarrels, from Moliere. Depit Amoureux. Duff’sIago, and H. Wallack’sCassio, were good— Mrs Duff’sDesdemona tolerable.

20. VI. Heard this morning Mr Little from 2. Timothy 2.8 “Remember that Jesus Christ of the seed of David was raised from the dead, according to my gospel”—from which he argued the doctrine of the Resurrection, and the single humanity of Christ. In the afternoon at the Presbyterian Church, Mr Baker preached from John 3.7. “Marvel not that I said unto thee, ye must be born again.” He said it was the first time, in two years that he had discourse to them upon this subject of regeneration; and he gave it, in all its power. In the Evening I heard again Mr Little, from 1. Corinthians 6.11. “And such were some of you: but ye are washed, but ye are sanctified, but ye are justified in the name of the Lord Jesus, and by the Spirit of our God.” Against the doctrine of regeneration. This Sermon, and that of Mr Baker, were like the two sides of an Argument in a Court of Law. After the morning service I asked Mr Bulfinch to lend me his Northwest Coast papers, and he promised that he would send them to me. I called at Mrs Peyton’s to visit the Florida-claim Commissioners, and left Cards— Met W. King, and asked him to call at my Office, to confer upon the subject of the Northern boundary— Had a visit from Commodore Chauncey lately returned from Boston— And in the Evening from C. King the Painter. H. Gilpin, called, and left a Letter of Introduction from Mr Hopkinson.

21. V.30. Swam with Antoine to the Bridge with the tide, and returned against it. One hour in the water, and the tide not running strong— I began a draft of Instruction to R. Rush upon the questions of maritime Law and neutrality. At the Office— Mr. W. G. D. Worthington, brought me a Letter from Dr Kent; and hinted at his wish to be appointed Secretary to the Slave-indemnity Commission— Baron Stackelberg came with a new Commission for a Swedish Vice-Consul at Charleston South-Carolina, the Christian name under his former Commission from the Swedish Consul-General Lorich having been erroneously given— The Count de Menou came to enquire if I had received any Letters from him yesterday, by the vessel from France— I had not, though I did receive despatches from D. Sheldon— I received a letter of 7. June from C. Raguet Consul at Rio de Janeiro, and answered it; and began also a draft of an Instruction to H. Middleton, upon the suppression of the Slave-trade. Mr Gilpin dined with us. After dinner I went out to the Columbia Mills, and George Johnson went with me over every part of the large building— He also shewed me the various places where he proposed alterations and repairs— After I returned home C. Hughes came in and passed an hour with me— He had been with the President who came back from Loudoun on Saturday.

22. V: A tumultuously busy day— Dr. Sewall was at my house to recommend a person, Abbot, as Marshal for the State of Mississippi— General Winder upon a visit. Mr Levi the Vice-Consul at the Danish Island of St. Thomas, wishing to return thither— He came afterwards to the Office, and went over again his long argument for prevailing upon the Danish Government to admit a Consul at St. Thomas’s. He wishes Mr Hughes may be charged with
the Negotiation and Hughes wishes the same. I was at the President’s with a multitude of papers most of which I left with him. At the Office I had visits from Mr Karthaus of Baltimore, and from Genl. William King of Maine, to whom I read my Letter of Instruction to R. Rush upon the subject of the Northern Boundary— Of which he expressed his entire approbation. I asked him to mark upon a map or describe in writing a boundary line, which he thought would be acceptable to the people of Maine and Massachusetts by way of compromise, with Great-Britain— He said on returning home in a few weeks, he would consult Governor Parris, Mr Mellen, and some others, and they would agree upon a line, which he thought would be satisfactory— And he would also consult Governor Eustis concerning it— Mrs Adams went with Mary Hellen and dined at Alexandria. In the Evening they went with George to the Theatre— Mr Gallatin and Mr Hughes spent the Evening with me— There was a total Eclipse of the Moon, from eight in the Evening—not over till past Midnight.

23. VI.Mr Bailey called at my house this morning, with the Virginian—L. Rice with a subscription for a Professorship of Mathematics and natural philosophy for the Columbian College. Mr James Dunlop came for the papers relating to the Columbia Mills, which he took and is to make out a conveyance for me. I have been by this affair most unseasonably diverted from the preparation of my Instructions to Mr Middleton and Mr Rush, to which I now must return with continual interruptions— A Mr Lewis of Louisiana called on me, with a Letter of Introduction from Governor Holmes of Mississippi to the President. At the Office, General Swift, Mr Gallatin and Mr Hughes, all upon their respective business— The General’s object being to obtain some assistance from the Government, and a loan of Astronomical Instruments for pursuing Captain Sabine’s Experiments to ascertain the length of the Pendulum vibrating seconds. Mr Hughes claims a second outfit as Chargé d’Affaires at Stockholm; and proposes to be employed on a special mission to Copenhagen— It is also proposed that he should be charged with the despatches that I am preparing for R. Rush and H. Middleton. Mr Gallatin is going to his Estate in the Western part of Pennsylvania. He did not absolutely decline returning to France; but thought the time indispensably required for the arrangement of his private affairs here would not permit him to go without a delay which may be detrimental to the public interest, and he does not wish that the Mission to France may be kept in abeyance to accommodate him— He spoke of the Claimants upon France; some of whom he had advised to petition Congress; and said there was another measure, which he had not suggested to them, and which the Government could not directly propose to them; but which if it comported with the President’s views, he would advise—which was that the Claimants should make application by Memorial to the President, that he would compound with France, and take a round sum to be distributed among them in full satisfaction— This was the only way in which the French Government would settle it— I said I thought the Claimants must find that out themselves. The Government could not advise them— I was at the President’s and met there Mr Thompson the Secretary of the Navy. We had company at Dinner— Messrs. Bailey, Brent, De Forrest, Gallatin and his Son James, Hughes, Jaudon, W. King, Levi, Seaton, Genl. Swift, Tazewell and Watkins. Messrs. Cowper, Pearce, Webster, White and Winder were invited, but have left the City or sent excuses— Judge White is much indisposed.

24. VI.George who has been several days unwell complained of a swelling in the throat which was very troublesome, and increased much in the course of the day— Mr Hughes called at my House, and left a second argument in support of his claim for a second outfit. He went this day to Baltimore; and is to embark the first of next Month at New-York, on his return to Sweden. A Mr DuMott, belonging to the State of New-York called, and brought with him a Letter of Introduction from Mr Woodcock. He is at Brown’s Hotel with his wife, and here only upon a transient visit. Mr D. Brent called, concerning the preparation of a Hall, in which the Slave indemnity Commission when assembled may hold their Meetings— I was at the President’s, and he directed a Meeting of the members of the Administration for to-morrow at one O’Clock, about Hughes’s claim— Mr. Calhoun was at the President’s— I am deeply engaged in preparing Instructions to R. Rush on Maritime Belligerent and Neutral Law— Short walk after dinner with Mrs Adams— Towards the close of the Evening came on a steady rain.

25. VI. Rain all night, and continual showers through the whole of this day till Evening. There was a Cabinet Meeting at the President’s; where all the papers relating to Mr Hughes’s claim to a second outfit were read and considered. All the members of the Administration were present, and all except myself for the allowance— I thought it allowable neither by the Letter, nor by the most liberal Construction of the Law—and there was no precedent to authorise it—This case itself I apprehend will be a fruitful one. Mr Crawford thought Hughes’s equitable claim was to the difference between what he had received as Secretary of Legation, while Mr Russell was at Stockholm after his return there, and the full Salary of Charge d’Affaires; but this would not be an equivalent for the outfit, and could by no construction of the Law be allowed, so that Mr Crawford acquiesced in the opinion of the other members that Hughes had an equitable claim to the outfit— It was also determined that Hughes should be authorised to go to Copenhagen to revive the claims upon the Danish Government— But the project of authorising him to act permanently as Chargé d’Affaires to Sweden and Denmark both, requires the concurrence of the Senate, and must be reserved for Consideration— Mr Gallatin called upon me this Evening. He leaves the City, the day after to-morrow— His Son James has been attacked with a fever, but is now convalescent— We talked of Literature; Science, and Arts— Cicero de Republica, Lambert’s Observations of the Latitude and Longitude of Washington, and Perkins’s new Steam Engine— George continued all this day very ill—his throat excessively inflamed, and with a high fever.

26. VI.B. O. Tyler came this morning for an engraved print of my father by Longacre, which he had sent me, and which I received yesterday. Visit from General Miller, Governor of the Territory of Arkansaw. His health has suffered from the climate— He said also there was great difficulty in the Territory on Account of his Commission as Governor not having been renewed in time— His first Commission expired in March 1822— By an inadvertence either at the President’s, in the omission to send a nomination to the Senate, or in the Senate by not acting upon it, the new Commission did not issue, till the next Session of the Senate.
In the interval he acted as Governor, presuming that his Commission had been renewed; till at the Commencement of the last Session of Congress, Mr Bates, the Delegate from the Territory informed me of the fact that Miller had not received his new Commission. It appeared on enquiry that his name had twice been sent from our Office to the President, for nomination; but no trace that the nomination had been sent to the Senate; although the President is confident that it was. After this Discovery the President sent a nomination to the Senate, of Miller as Governor, from the expiration of his former Commission; but the Senate confirmed only the nomination, without retrospect. So that all the Acts of Miller as Governor, for nearly a year, are without warrant of Law, and it has thrown the whole territory into confusion— It is doubtful whether even an Act of Congress could remedy the evil. George Johnson came with a draft of the Deed to be executed by his father— Nearly copied from that I had made— But the Deed from Dunlop to me is not yet executed— I drafted a Mortgage of the Estate where I live, and took it to Mr Smith Cashier of the U.S. Branch Bank, offering it as in part security for the Note I am to give them— He approved it, and Mary Hellen copied it for execution. I opened an account, also at the Bank and deposited the proceeds received yesterday from Philadelphia, of 11500 dollars six per Cent Stocks which I sent there to be transferred. I was also deeply engaged in preparing Instructions for R. Rush, and sent to the President, the Draft of the maritime Neutrality Convention— Visits from General Brown, with Lieutt. Kirby— The General is going to Long Branch for Sea-Bathing— At the Office, Mr M’Duffie called to recommend Mr Watts, as Secretary of Legation to Chili. He said something also of general politics; particularly in the State of New-York— I have been all this day and yesterday in deep distress for George; he had yesterday 36 leaches applied to his throat, the inflammation of which has made it scarcely possible for him to speak or to swallow. He has had a high fever, and has taken for three days no sustenance but tea— This Evening an abscess broke in his throat, from which we hope relief. Blisters were also this Evening applied to it— Antoine yesterday gave me a second notice that he and his wife would leave us.

27. VI.George was better— I hope out of danger; but exceedingly weak and exhausted. Still internally feverish; and confined chiefly to his bed— Heard Mr Little this Morning; from Zechariah 14.9. “And the Lord shall be king over all the Earth: in that day there shall be one Lord, and his name one.”— It was a strong argumentative Unitarian Sermon: denying even the pre-existence of Christ; and explaining as figurative language, all the passages in the Scriptures of opposite sense— I spoke to Mr Bailey, and he came to my house, and took a sheet of the draft of Instructions which I am preparing for R. Rush, to be copied— In the afternoon I heard at the Presbyterian Church Mr Baker—from John 5.14—“Behold, thou art made whole: sin no more, lest a worse thing come unto thee.” He exhorted us to consider how many worse things might befall us, than a palsy of 38 years— Mr Little’s Evening service was from Psalm 94—8.9.10. “Understand; ye brutish among the people: and ye fools, when will ye be wise?— He that planted the ear, shall he not hear? he that formed the eye, shall he not see?— He that chastiseth the heathen, shall not he correct? he that teacheth man knowledge, shall not he know?” An eloquent encomium upon the Psalms, and the omnipotence of God— I visited at Noon this
day Judge White of Tennessee, who is recovering from indisposition: and called at Brown’s Hotel to see Mr and Mrs Du Mott; but they had left the City— I met Genl. Miller.

28. V:30. A Mr J. S. Scott came to the Office, soliciting to be employed as a Clerk, or on some business for which occasional aid of copying is required. I called at the President’s with the Draft of Instructions to R. Rush, to accompany the project of a Convention to regulate neutral, and Belligerent rights in time of War. The President had suggested a single alteration, in the Draft of a Convention which I had sent him on Saturday— Mr Calhoun came in, while I was reading to the President the draft of the Instruction; and after I had finished, started several doubts as to the propriety of proposing this project at-all. He was confident it would not be accepted by Great-Britain; and I have no expectation that it will, at this time— But my object is to propose it to Russia, and France, and to all the maritime Powers of Europe, as well as to Great-Britain! We discussed for some time its expediency; I appealed to the primitive policy of this Country as exemplified in the first Treaty with Prussia. I said the Seed was then first sown; and had born a single plant, which the fury of the revolutionary tempest had since swept away. I thought the present a moment eminently auspicious for sowing the same seed a second time; and although I had no hope, it would now take root in England, I had the most cheering confidence, that it would ultimately bear a harvest of happiness to mankind and of glory to this Union— Mr Calhoun still suggested doubts, but no positive objections, and the President directed me to send the draft of the Articles round to the members of the administration, and to call a Meeting of them for to-morrow at one. I was not surprized at Mr Calhoun’s doubts— My plan involves nothing less than a Revolution in the Laws of War— A great amelioration in the condition of man— Is it the dream of a visionary? or is it the great and practicable conception of a benefactor of mankind? I believe it the latter, and I believe this to be precisely the time for proposing it to the world— Should it even fail, it will be honourable to have proposed it— Founded on Justice, Humanity and Benevelence, it can in no Event bear bitter fruits— George is recovering slowly from his indisposition.

29. V:30.Mr D. Brent called upon me this morning with Mr Charles Walsh of Baltimore— The meeting at the President’s was delayed about an hour by a very heavy thunder Shower. Mr Wirt was absent from it, from indisposition— The draft of a Convention was read, and discussed— Mr Calhoun still intimated doubts as to the expediency of proposing it; but more faintly than yesterday. Mr. Crawford made no express objection, but declared his full conviction, that Great-Britain would accept no part of it which it would be useful or desirable to us that she should accept. He also objected to some of the details, and suggested alterations in several of the Articles; some of which the President approved— His chief objection was to the Article, which authorizes the punishment of persons taking Commissions for privateering from foreign Powers as Pirates— Though we have it already in almost every one of our Treaties. But in this objection he was alone— Calhoun doubted whether by proposing the whole Convention at once, we might not fail of obtaining what we might perhaps obtain if presented singly, an arrangement of the impressment question. But Crawford thought Great-Britain would never settle the impressment question by Treaty— She would let it die a natural death, by abstaining to issue orders to her naval Officers to impress men
from our vessels— Mr Thompson declared himself in the most explicit manner, in favour of my whole project; and after the meeting was over, the President directed me to forward by express to Mr Hughes at New York, the whole Letter of Instruction, as it was, and the whole draft of a Convention with one alteration suggested by Mr Crawford— I had sent to Baron Tuyll requesting him to call at my Office at four O’Clock, and I found him there on my return from the President’s— I told him that besides the subject of the North-west Coast question, Mr Middleton would be instructed to communicate with the imperial Government upon two other very important subjects—that of constituting the Slave-trade piracy by the Law of Nations, and that of the regulation of neutral and belligerent rights— I explained to him briefly and in general terms the principles upon which Mr Rush was authorised to negotiate in England, upon both these points; and observed to him that the President proposed to present the same principles for Negotiation with Russia. I added that I had sent for him to give him notice of this, that he might have the opportunity of first communicating it to his Government— He thanked me in terms of the warmest acknowledgment; and appeared to be exceedingly gratified at the substance of our proposals in both cases. He asked me whether he should yet have time to prepare a despatch to go by Mr Hughes— And said he should wish to have an opportunity of shewing it to me before sending it. I told him I should send my despatches by an express, to go early to-morrow Morning for New-York— If he would write his despatch and send it to me at any time this Evening before Midnight, I would deliver it in charge of the express. I should be grateful for the perusal of it, if he would send it to me open. He accordingly sent me about ten this Evening a despatch containing a succinct account of our interview, with the request that after reading, and if necessary correcting it, I would send it back to him to seal up; as I did. He sent it again about midnight, sealed and directed to Count Lieven at London.

30. V:30.Mr Ironside, whom I send as Express to New-York with the Packets for Mr Hughes, called this morning as I had directed, and I delivered to him Baron Tuyll’s despatch for Count Lieven— Mr George Hay called at the Office with a Letter from one of his friends recommending a person for the appointment of Marshal in the State of Mississippi— I wrote to Mr M. Sterling at Watertown, on Lake Ontario— And at the Office, answered the Count de Menou’s Note communicating the determination of the French Government not to commission privateers during the present War— Mr George Johnson called at my house this Evening. He has received the Deed from his father, executed, and said Mr Dunlop would come with him to-morrow and execute his— But the business does not proceed so smoothly as he had expected— He finds that more considerable repairs must be made, than he had supposed would be necessary, and that they will scarcely be able to go to work in less than ten days— His assistant has not yet arrived; nor can he find the key of the warehouse at Georgetown. These are circumstances of no encouraging tendency, but I have laid my account for many such. My Son George who is recovering, asked two days since my consent for him to engage himself to Mary Hellen— I asked him this Evening for how long he expected the engagement to continue— He said no limited time; perhaps five or six years; till his prospects would warrant his marrying— I gave my consent on a certain condition, to which he fully assented. Mrs Adams went this Evening to Mrs Frye’s— Her child is in a very dangerous state of health. I passed the Evening at home with George, yet confined to his chamber.

31. V:15.Dr Thornton and Mr Reynolds two Justices of the Peace came, to my house and took the acknowledgment by myself and my wife, of a deed of mortgage of it, to Richard Smith Cashier of the Bank of the United States (Branch) for the use of the President, Directors and Company of the Bank, to secure the payment to them of a Note from me for 20000 dollars. G. Johnson came to finish the business, and Mr Dunlop was at the Office with a deed to me ready for Execution. But he had not an express Letter of Assent and Release from the Bank of Columbia, which I had expected, and the Directors of that Bank wish the final execution of the Deeds to be postponed, for a few days, upon a proposal from them to the Bank of the United States by which they might receive cash instead of a credit for this payment— Judge Thruston came to my house, in a state of the most extreme agitation of mind. He told me much of his History— He is a man of great integrity and purity of character—intelligent, learned, with an elegant taste and great love of Literature— But afflicted with nervous irritability, beyond any man I ever knew. Always sensible of his own condition, and unable to controul his feelings— He wishes now to make a short tour into Virginia. He will call on me again— I was at the President’s with the draft of a Note to the Count de Menou which he approved. Dined at Mr George Graham’s with a Company of twenty men—Foreign Missions and Public Officers of the Departments— Mr Crawford and Mr Thompson not there— Mr Calhoun told me, that upon Reflection he thought better of my project for abolishing private War upon the Sea than he had at first— Evening at home— Captain Spence, and Dr Huntt were here.

Day. For the distribution of the time, like the last Month, with the exception of the sittings to King the Painter— The important labour of the Month has been the preparation of Instructions to R. Rush and to H. Middleton upon the Northwest Coast question, and upon the project of a Convention for the regulation of neutral and Belligerent rights. These are both important transactions; and the latter especially one which will warrant the special invocation of wisdom from above— When I think, if it possibly could succeed, what a real and solid blessing it would be to the human race, I can scarcely guard myself from a Spirit of enthusiasm, which it becomes me to distrust. I feel that I could die for it, with joy, and that if my last Moments could be cheered with this consciousness of having contributed to it, I could go before the throne of omnipotence with a plea for mercy, and with a consciousness of not having lived in vain for the world of mankind. It has been for more than thirty years my prayer to God, that this might be my lot upon Earth. To render signal service to my Country, and to my Species— For the specific object, the end and the means I have relied alike upon the goodness of God— What they were or would be I knew not. For “it is not in Man that walketh to direct his steps.” I have rendered services to my Country, but not such as could satisfy my own ambition— But this offers the specific object which I have desired— And why should not the hearts of the Rulers of mankind, be turned to approve and establish it? I have opened my Soul to the hope, though with trembling— In the course of this month also I have made a disposal of a large portion of my private property which may have great influence upon the remainder of my days— This too cannot prosper, but with the blessing of Heaven which I implore— In the preparation for my retirement to private life, the main object of my pursuit is a state of mind over which I may preserve entire controul.
